Json Exam Document Parser — jsonexamparser
text: function takes series options obtained parse_args parameter opt. "examples" section provides options can parse. within options, --file option mandatory. file option provides 'LaTeX' file name search lines preamble %!TexExamRandomizer within first 200 lines. options finds tags, passes function CreateRandomExams. Note tags must respect JSON format, . needs written within double quotes.

title: Json Exam Document Parser — jsonexamparser
text: opt Options parsed parse_args. function expects series options, example code exemplifies options function understands.

title: Json Exam Document Parser — jsonexamparser
text: options can found vignette("ExamOptions", package = "TexExamRandomizer") options called "command line" options vignette given function opt, rest options read directly document specified --file <filename>

title: Json Exam Document Parser — jsonexamparser
code: if (FALSE) { #!/bin/Rscript #This example showcases the type of script this jsonparser might be used on. # You can still use it without a script, # just by adding a list that has the same names as the list provided in opt library(optparse) option_list <- list(     make_option(         c("--file"),         action = "store",         default = NULL,         type = 'character',         help = "Filename of the Tex File"     ),     make_option(         c("--table"),         action = "store",         default = NULL,         type = 'character',         help = "Filename of the table to break down. It overwrites the values written on the file"     ),     make_option(         c("-n", "--noutput"),         action = "store",         default = NULL,         type = "integer",         help = "Number of output Versions"     ),     make_option(         c("-q", "--nquestions"),         action = "store",         default = NULL,         type = "character",         help = "Number of output questions"     ),     make_option(         c("-s", "--seed"),         action = "store",         default = NULL,         type = "integer",         help = "Seed for any randomization done"     ),     make_option(         c("-c", "--compile"),         action = "store_true",         default = FALSE,         type = "logical",         help = "Should the output folder be compiled or not"     ),     make_option(         c("--xelatex"),         action = "store_true",         default = FALSE,         type = "logical",         help = "Should we use xelatex to compile or not"     ),     make_option(         c("-d", "--debug"),         action = "store_true",         default = FALSE,         type = "logical",         help = "If debugging, it doesn't remove auxiliary files"     ) )   #### PARSING OPTIONS #### #### opt <-     parse_args(         OptionParser(option_list = option_list),         positional_arguments = TRUE     )  # Let's assume the file was the example file testfile <-     system.file(         "extdata",         "ExampleTexDocuments",         "exam_testing_nquestions.tex", #Test exam that doesn't require a table         package = "TexExamRandomizer")  # To prevent modifying the file system in examples temporalfile <- paste(tempfile(), ".tex", sep = "")  file.copy(testfile, temporalfile)  opt$options$file <- temporalfile    jsonexamparser(opt) }

title: Json Homework Parser — jsonhwparser
code: if (FALSE) { #!/bin/Rscript #This example showcases the type of script this jsonparser might be used on. # You can still use it without a script, # just by adding a list that has the same names as the list provided in opt library(optparse) option_list <- list(     make_option(         c("--file"),         action = "store",         default = NULL,         type = 'character',         help = "Filename of the Tex File"     ),     make_option(         c("--table"),         action = "store",         default = NULL,         type = 'character',         help = "Filename of the table to break down. It overwrites the values written on the file"     ),     make_option(         c("-s", "--seed"),         action = "store",         default = NULL,         type = "integer",         help = "Seed for any randomization done"     ),     make_option(         c("-c", "--compile"),         action = "store_true",         default = FALSE,         type = "logical",         help = "Should the output folder be compiled or not"     ),     make_option(         c("--xelatex"),         action = "store_true",         default = FALSE,         type = "logical",         help = "Should we use xelatex to compile or not"     ),     make_option(         c("-d", "--debug"),         action = "store_true",         default = FALSE,         type = "logical",         help = "If debugging, it doesn't remove auxiliary files"     ) )   #### PARSING OPTIONS #### #### opt <-     parse_args(         OptionParser(option_list = option_list),         positional_arguments = TRUE     )  # Let's assume the file was the example file testfile <-     system.file(         "extdata",         "ExampleTexDocuments",         "exam_testing_nquestions.tex", #Test exam that doesn't require a table         package = "TexExamRandomizer")  # To prevent modifying the file system in examples temporalfile <- paste(tempfile(), ".tex", sep = "")  file.copy(testfile, temporalfile)  opt$options$file <- temporalfile    jsonhwparser(opt) }
